The correct term is not "period" when it comes to British English, it is "full stop". However, I was incorrect to use "dot" and you have my thanks.

As for "those", it is inappropriate in a situation where you are currently watching the video, so your reference point differs depending on what you do or do not see.
You're supposed to put the quotation mark after the comma, and the correct term is not "dot," it is "period." Also, in this situation it's better to use "those" as opposed to "these" or "this."

The common word "worm" also applies to caterpillars.

(/wikipedia)Invertebrate animals commonly called "worms" include annelids (earthworms), nematodes (roundworms), platyhelminthes (flatworms), marine polychaete worms (bristle worms), marine nemertean worms ("bootlace worms"), marine Chaetognatha (arrow worms), priapulid worms, and insect larvae such as caterpillars, grubs, and maggots.  (/wikipedia)

What he's saying is that if an ant weighs 1 milligram, it can move 5 milligrams of weight . When 100 ants move something, they can move 5,000 milligrams. 5000/100=50. So each ant is moving 50 times it's weight. 

The sum is greater than it's parts.

All worker and soldier ants are female. Male ants (at least in most species) are flies that fly to new colonies to provide genetic material to new colonies. All ants have gender, but only queen and drone (male) ants reproduce.
